May 18, 1956
Associate and Affiliate members pay flO.OO a year. For this fee members
recoil our monthly Newsletters the$ various reports and surveys we publish
periodically; services of our Placement Service, television engineer, legal
counsel, management consultant, etc.; plus the normal day to day services,
information, and advice that any national organisation gives its members.
Under separate cover we are sending you samples of some of the materials
we regularly send our members, plus other items which will give you more
information about the Association. Of course. Associate and Affiliate mem¬
bers do not receive as many of these materials as regularly as Active mem¬
bers do*
In addition. Active members with radio stations may use the facilities of
the MASS Radio network upon payment of an annual assessment foe. The Het-
work distributes approximately eight hours of programming, by tape record¬
ing, weekly, to members subscribing to its service. This fee is also based
on power (with the same power classifications as membership) and a new sta¬
tion does not have to pay the full foe until the third year it is in the
Network. The fees ares
3rd year
Glass A
500.00
300.00
Class B
Class C
251.00
150.00
375.00
225.00
Stations must also pay postage both ways on the tapes shipped to and from
Network Headquarters here in Urbana, Illinois. Still even a Class A sta¬
tion paying its full third-year rate is plying only a little over £2.00
an hour for better than 400 hours of programming from the Network in a
year. This is about the most inexpensive programming a station can do.
If, after you have a chance to look over the materials we're sending, you
have any questions, I shall be most happy to answer the®, and I'm sure
Mr. Mamet would welccrae an opportunity to talk with you about HU58 mem¬
bership.
Sincerely,
Harold E. Hill
